Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Biomimetic Self-Assembly: Physical State and the Barrier Function to Water Permeation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports Professor Sunghee Lee of Iona College to study how supramolecular self-assemblies at micrometer-sized liquid-liquid interfaces control the passage of water. The study promotes our understanding of how living cells can selectively retain and release their water content. Such water controlling mechanisms are essential to understanding not only life's origins but also the functions of major organs such as the skin and kidneys. More broadly, the project has a potential to contribute to human health and clean water applications that rely on the retention and elimination of water and waste. The research enables training for a large number of undergraduate research participants in the project. The research team further broadens the impact of their work by developing outreach seminars and science symposia for high school students and teachers that inspire and engage students to enter science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields, particularly those from underrepresented groups. Professor Lee and her students travel to the University of Tokyo in Japan to conduct experiments on high-throughput device fabrication obtaining a global perspective on science.

This research is focused on elucidating how supramolecular self-assemblies at micron-sized liquid-liquid interfaces can serve as controllable barriers for the passage of water. The team of researchers, Professor Lee and undergraduate students at Iona College, will investigate the directionality of the water movement, and balance between permeability and stability in protocell models through experimental activities strategized to determine the water permeability parameters and energy of activation for osmotic flow, electrical properties of capacitance and leakage current, diffusional water permeability, and adhesion energy. Upon successful completion, this research could provide fundamental insights into how lipid asymmetry plays a role in organismal water homeostasis, and the balance between stability and permeability in prebiotic cellular models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In living organisms, lipid membranes are vital interfaces. These membranes' structure and properties are greatly influenced by the types of lipids they are made of and the surrounding environment. We are studying how different combinations of lipids and other molecules around them impact the structure and characteristics of cell membranes, using a model called the droplet interface bilayer. This research is important for understanding how cells work and stay balanced, which is key for overall health. By studying the structure and property of lipid membranes and the impact other surrounding molecules can have on the cell membranes, we hope to learn more about how drug molecules, plant chemicals, and 2D nanomaterials affect cell membranes. We also use Raman spectroscopy, electrical and thermal property measurements to observe and measure how cell membranes sensitively respond to the surrounding conditions and exposure to other molecules. Our goal is to uncover how these molecules can influence cells and the environment, particularly in terms of ecotoxicity. Our research aims to provide valuable insights that can contribute to improving health and environmental safety. In another aspect of research, we have demonstrate the creation of model early cell membrane using DIB technology to make membranes similar to those found in early cells. These membranes are made of fatty acids. We found that these membranes are stable and allow some molecules to pass through, which are important parameters needed for a viable cell. Our research has revealed that the balance between the stability and ability of these membranes to let substances pass through depends on the chemical nature of the composition, especially length of the fatty acid chains. Our research findings have been disseminated to communities of interest via peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations. A total of 6 peer-reviewed publications are made with 41 undergraduate student co-author names. Over 70 presentations have been made by the PI and her undergraduate students, at the national, regional and local level.


The projects funded by this proposal have continuously allowed an impressive number of undergraduate students to participate in research under the mentorship of the PI, together with an excellent post-graduation track record. The commitment of the PI to workforce development has created a perfect opportunity to help elevate these students to be better situated to immediately enter the national workforce. The students are given a progressively-increasing level of responsibility at an early stage of their career, even as early as freshman year. Therefore, it is the belief of the PI that the students involved in NSF-funded research, by and large are not merely assisting in the achievement of the scientific goals of the project, but are broadening their skill set to have both general and specific applicability to the workforce: time management; mental discipline; attention to detail; follow-through; and of course knowledge of laboratory chemistry techniques, safety, and the scientific method. For the entire duration of this grant, 26 research students graduated (including the ones who will be graduating in Spring 2024), 16 have progressed or are progressing to their postgraduate training programs (PhD, MD, MS) and 10 students in FT employed in STEM field. The PI is also actively involved in outreach activities to the community through various high school partnership events: science outreach seminars and an annual science symposium for the local high school. The new interdisciplinary course and laboratory modules inspired by the NSF grant activities have been developed and incorporated in upper-level chemistry and biochemistry courses. Additionally, the research instrumentation acquired with the support of NSF funding has continued to be essential resources to overall facility of the chemistry program, as they are incorporated for teaching in many undergraduate courses, allowing large number of students to be exposed to high quality state of the art tools to foster the engaged learning that enables them to increase their reasoning and critical thinking skills. The PI facilitates joint mentorship with respective faculty members for enhanced interdisciplinary educational experiences. For example, one student was involved in surface modification of soft nanoparticles with biochemistry faculty member, and three separate students have been involved in computational modeling of the biological membranes. The growth of teaching and research infrastructure for sceince and education has been greatly enhanced as a result of NSF support. This will have a significant positive impact not only on the advancement of scientific knowledge, but also for the production of an even greater number of undergraduates from underrepresented groups pursuing advanced degrees in chemical science, and the promotion of their future success.
